posts.title: Random Acts of Kindness at the Library
posts.text: From the Bronx through Manhattan to Staten Island, staff members at The New York Public Library regularly witness random acts of kindness. Here, we've collected just a few of these heartwarming interactions.

posts.title: 5 Trash-Talking Letters Between Writers
posts.text: From subtle burns to scathing critiques, here are a few choice examples of writers letting each other know how they *really* feel.

posts.title: (Totally Free!) Things You Can Do With Your Library Card
posts.text: With your NYPL card, you get access to amazing resources. Learn a language, gain a career skill, and more.

posts.title: Writers on Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language”
posts.text: If you’ve ever thought of yourself as a writer, chances are that you have opinions about George Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language.” First published in 1946, it has since become required reading for intro-level writing classes, as well as an obligatory citation when discussing politics and rhetoric.

posts.title: 11 Facts About NYPL for #AprilFactsDay
posts.text: The New York Public Library's Stephen A. Schwarzman building opened on Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street in 1911. One of NYC's iconic landmarks, it welcomes millions of visitors a year to discover its inspiring public spaces, unparalleled research collections, and vibrant programs and exhibitions. But that's not the whole story about the building behind the Library Lions.

posts.title: Why We Love LeVar Burton
posts.text: LeVar Burton is an actor, director, and author. To library folk and other bookworms, however, he is likely best known as the host and executive producer of Reading Rainbow.

posts.title: 10 Worldview-Expanding TV Series for World Television Day
posts.text: World Television Day isn't just another made up pseudo-holiday. To honor the intended spirit of World Television Day, why not turn on your tube and tune into some worldview-expanding programming?

posts.title: John Lennon's New York City
posts.text: Born October 9, 1940, John Lennon spent his post-Beatles years (1971–1980) living and working in New York City. Commemorate Lennon's birthday and life in NYC by exploring an interactive map of landmarks, suggested books, and more.
